A 14-year-old girl comes to the physician with her father for evaluation of her short stature. She feels well overall, but is concerned because all of her friends are taller than her. Her birth weight was normal. Her father reports he had a short stature during his teenage years; he is currently 177 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall. She is at the 2ndpercentile for height and 35th percentile for weight. Breast development is Tanner stage 2. Pubic and axillary hair is absent. An x-ray of the left hand and wrist shows a bone age of 11 years. Which of the following is the most appropriate next best step in management?
A.Pelvic ultrasound
B.Measure serum dehydroepiandrosterone levels
C.Reassurance and follow-up
D.MRI of the brain

The girl's short stature is concerning, and her father's history of short stature suggests a familial component. The fact that she is at the 2nd percentile for height and 35th percentile for weight, with a bone age of 11 years, indicates that she is not growing at the expected rate for her age. This could be due to a growth hormone deficiency or a constitutional delay in growth and puberty.

A. Pelvic ultrasound is not indicated at this time as there is no indication of a pelvic or reproductive issue.

B. Measuring serum dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) levels is not appropriate as DHEA is not a growth hormone; it is a steroid hormone that is not typically used to assess growth hormone deficiency.

C. Reassurance and follow-up are appropriate if there is no concern for a serious underlying condition. However, given the discrepancy between her chronological age and bone age, it is important to investigate further to rule out a growth hormone deficiency.

D. An MRI of the brain is not indicated at this time as there is no suspicion of a brain tumor or other central nervous system pathology that would cause growth hormone deficiency.

Given the information provided, the most appropriate next step in management would be to measure growth hormone levels to assess for growth hormone deficiency. This would help to determine if she requires treatment with growth hormone to improve her growth.

So, the answer is B. Measure serum dehydroepiandrosterone levels. Therefore, the answer is B

A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of facial swelling that started 5 days ago. Two weeks ago, he had a sore throat that resolved spontaneously. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 107/min, and blood pressure is 94/67 mm Hg. Examination shows pitting edema of the upper and lower extremities as well as periorbital edema. The abdomen is mildly distended. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.1 g/dL
Serum
Albumin 2.1 g/dL
Total cholesterol 270 mg/dL
Triglycerides 175 mg/dL
Urine
Blood negative
Glucose negative
Protein 4+
Leukocyte esterase negative
A renal biopsy of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?"
A.Mesangial proliferation on light microscopy
B.Subepithelial dense deposits on electron microscopy
C.Deposits of IgG and C3 at the glomerular basement membrane on immunofluoresence
D.Normal light microscopy findings
D

cot:
<|assistant|>
The clinical presentation of the 5-year-old boy with facial swelling, pitting edema, periorbital edema, and abdominal distension, along with laboratory findings of hypoalbuminemia (low albumin), hyperlipidemia (high total cholesterol and triglycerides), and proteinuria (protein in the urine), is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and edema.

The most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease (MCD), which is a primary glomerular disease. MCD is characterized by a loss of foot processes of podocytes and a normal appearance on light microscopy. However, on electron microscopy, there may be effacement of the foot processes, which is a hallmark of MCD.

The other options listed are not typical findings in MCD:

A. Mesangial proliferation on light microscopy is more characteristic of mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis, which is not the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.
B. Subepithelial dense deposits on electron microscopy are more characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis or dense deposit disease, which are less common causes of nephrotic syndrome in children.
C. Deposits of IgG and C3 at the glomerular basement membrane on immunofluoresence are more characteristic of post-infectious glomerulonephritis, which is not the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.
D. Normal light microscopy findings are not typical for nephrotic syndrome, as MCD often shows a normal appearance on light microscopy.

Given the clinical presentation and the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, the renal biopsy of this patient is most likely to show normal light microscopy findings, which is characteristic of minimal change disease.

So, the answer is D. Normal light microscopy findings. Therefore, the answer is D

A 60-year-old man is referred to a dermatologist by his family physician for management of a rare case of dermatitis that has not responded to standard therapy with corticosteroids. The patient’s medical history is unremarkable, and he is currently working reduced hours at his job as an accountant. Physical examination reveals confluent scaly patches, plaques, and generalized erythroderma along the torso and lower extremities (see image). There is also a solid skin lesion with a diameter greater than 1 cm. The dermatologist suspects a malignancy and orders a biopsy. Which of the following is the most accurate description of this condition?
A.Vascular tumor containing spindle cells
B.Tumor arising from the folliculosebaceous–apocrine germ
C.Tumor arising from cutaneous T cells
D.Tumor arising from epidermal keratinocytes
C

cot:
<|assistant|>
The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a skin condition that has not responded to standard therapy with corticosteroids and is characterized by confluent scaly patches, plaques, and generalized erythroderma, along with a solid skin lesion greater than 1 cm in diameter. The dermatologist's suspicion of a malignancy is a reasonable one given the lack of response to corticosteroids and the presence of a large, solid skin lesion.

Let's review the options:

A. Vascular tumor containing spindle cells - This description is consistent with a diagnosis of angiosarcoma, a rare and aggressive form of skin cancer that arises from the endothelial cells lining blood vessels.

B. Tumor arising from the folliculosebaceous–apocrine germ - This description is consistent with a diagnosis of a skin adnexal tumor, such as a basal cell carcinoma or a squamous cell carcinoma, which are the most common types of skin cancer.

C. Tumor arising from cutaneous T cells - This description is consistent with a diagnosis of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, such as mycosis fungoides or Sézary syndrome, which are types of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that affect the skin.

D. Tumor arising from epidermal keratinocytes - This description is consistent with a diagnosis of a keratinocyte-derived skin cancer, such as basal cell carcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma.

Given the patient's symptoms and the dermatologist's suspicion of a malignancy, the most likely diagnosis is a skin adnexal tumor, which is consistent with the description of a tumor arising from the folliculosebaceous–apocrine germ.

So, the answer is B. Tumor arising from the folliculosebaceous–apocrine germ. Therefore, the answer is B

A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has been feeling very stressed over the past several months. During this period, she has found it difficult to relax. She states that her head is full of worries. She works at an accountant's office and reports difficulty in concentrating on her work. She has been working longer shifts because one of her coworkers is on vacation and reports feeling more tired than usual. She is married and frequently fights with her husband. The patient states that in order to deal with her stress, she goes shopping. While shopping, she steals small trivial items and feels immediately relieved thereafter. She discards the objects she steals and has feelings of shame and guilt about her actions. Her husband is concerned about her behavior, but she is unable to stop shoplifting. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she is oriented to person, place, and time. She reports feeling anxious. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A.Administration of lithium
B.Interpersonal therapy
C.Psychodynamic psychotherapy
D.Cognitive behavioral therapy
D

cot:
<|assistant|>
The patient's symptoms suggest that she is experiencing significant stress and anxiety, which is affecting her daily life and relationships. She is having difficulty relaxing, concentrating, and sleeping, and she is engaging in compulsive behavior (shoplifting) to relieve her stress. This behavior is likely a form of impulse control disorder, which is characterized by the inability to resist an impulse, drive, or temptation to perform an act that is harmful to the person or to others.

Given the options provided:

A. Administration of lithium is typically used to treat bipolar disorder, which is not indicated in this case as there is no mention of mood swings or other symptoms that would suggest bipolar disorder.

B. Interpersonal therapy is a short-term, structured therapy that focuses on the patient's relationships and how they may be contributing to their symptoms. While this could be helpful in addressing the patient's marital issues and stress at work, it may not be the most appropriate next step for her shoplifting behavior.

C. Psychodynamic psychotherapy is a type of therapy that focuses on the unconscious aspects of the mind and how they influence behavior. While this approach can be helpful in understanding the underlying causes of behavior, it may not be the most immediate or effective treatment for impulse control disorders like shoplifting.

D. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a type of psychotherapy that focuses on the relationship between thoughts, feelings, and behaviors. It is particularly effective in treating anxiety disorders, impulse control disorders, and other mental health conditions. CBT can help the patient identify and change negative thought patterns and behaviors that contribute to her stress and shoplifting.

Given the patient's symptoms and the need for immediate intervention to address her shoplifting behavior, cognitive behavioral therapy is the most appropriate next step in management.

So, the answer is D. Cognitive behavioral therapy. Therefore, the answer is D

A 65-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a change in his behavior over the past few months. Initially, the patient was noted to be behaving inappropriately including using foul language and grabbing people unexpectedly. This has progressed to a worsening of his memory and trouble caring for himself. His temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 162/103 mmHg, pulse is 83/min, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an elderly man who laughs inappropriately at times and who is a poor historian. When he is engaged in conversation, he exhibits word finding difficulty and is rather inattentive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A.Alzheimer dementia
B.Frontotemporal dementia
C.Kluver-Bucy syndrome
D.Vascular dementia
B

cot:
<|assistant|>
The patient's symptoms include a change in behavior, inappropriate language, memory problems, and difficulty caring for himself. These symptoms are suggestive of a neurodegenerative disorder affecting the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain. The symptoms of inappropriate behavior, language, and memory issues are not typical for vascular dementia, which is more commonly associated with a history of strokes or other vascular events.

Alzheimer's dementia typically presents with memory problems and cognitive decline, but it is less likely to cause the behavioral changes seen in this patient, such as the use of foul language and grabbing people unexpectedly.

Kluver-Bucy syndrome is a rare condition that typically occurs after bilateral damage to the temporal lobes and is characterized by changes in sexual behavior, hyperorality, and visual agnosia. While the patient's behavior may be inappropriate, the other symptoms do not fit the classic presentation of Kluver-Bucy syndrome.

Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that affects the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain. It is characterized by changes in personality and behavior, including disinhibition, apathy, and loss of empathy, which align with the patient's symptoms of inappropriate behavior, poor self-care, and difficulty with attention and word finding.

Given the patient's symptoms and the areas of the brain that are typically affected in FTD, the most likely diagnosis is frontotemporal dementia.

So, the answer is B. Frontotemporal dementia. Therefore, the answer is B

An 11-month-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother for a rash on his trunk, which he has had for the past 2 days. She notes that he is eating less and is more cranky than usual. His birth history is insignificant, and his immunizations are up to date. Vital signs include: temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 98/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min. The rash features thin-walled, fluid-filled blisters that rupture easily. Fluid samples from the lesions are sent for analysis to a microbiology lab. The results reveal an infection by the gram-positive bacterium Staphylococcus aureus. The patient is diagnosed with staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome. Which of the following is involved with the primary defense in response to the bacteria and toxins produced by this organism?
A.Immunoglobulin- IgG
B.Immunoglobulin- IgD
C.Immunoglobulin- IgA
D.Immunoglobulin- IgM
D

cot:
<|assistant|>
Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) is caused by an infection with Staphylococcus aureus, which produces an exotoxin known as epidermolytic toxin (exfoliatin). This toxin targets desmoglein 1, a protein that holds the cells of the epidermis together. When the toxin binds to desmoglein 1, it causes the cells to separate, leading to the formation of blisters and the characteristic "scalded skin" appearance.

The primary defense against bacterial infections, including those caused by Staphylococcus aureus, is the immune system. The immune system produces antibodies, which are proteins that recognize and bind to specific antigens on pathogens. These antibodies can then activate the immune system to destroy the pathogen.

The immunoglobulins (Igs) that are involved in the primary defense against bacterial infections include IgG, IgM, and IgA. IgG is the most abundant immunoglobulin in the blood and is responsible for neutralizing toxins and pathogens. IgM is the first immunoglobulin to be produced in response to an infection and is important for opsonization and complement activation. IgA is found in mucosal secretions and is important for local defense against pathogens.

Given that the question asks about the primary defense against the bacteria and toxins produced by Staphylococcus aureus, the most relevant immunoglobulin would be the one that is involved in neutralizing toxins. Since IgG is the immunoglobulin that is primarily responsible for neutralizing toxins, it is the most appropriate answer.

So, the answer is A. Immunoglobulin- IgG. Therefore, the answer is A

A transvaginal ultrasound shows an intrauterine heteroechoic mass with numerous anechoic spaces and no identifiable fetus or amniotic fluid. C.Yolk sac tumor

The ultrasound findings described are characteristic of a condition known as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). PCOS is a common endocrine disorder that affects women of reproductive age. It is characterized by the presence of multiple small cysts within the ovaries, which are typically less than 10 mm in diameter and are often referred to as "pearl-on-a-string" cysts due to their appearance on ultrasound.

The presence of multiple thin-walled, septated cysts with clear content in the ovaries is indicative of PCOS. These cysts are not chocolate cysts (A), which are typically associated with endometriosis and are filled with old blood. Corpus luteum cysts (B) are usually single and are associated with ovulation, not the multiple cysts described. Yolk sac tumors (C) are a type of germ cell tumor that would not present with the described ultrasound findings. Theca leutein cysts (D) are associated with hyperstimulation of the ovaries, which is not the case here.

Given the description of the ovarian findings, the most likely cause is polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

A 75-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her son because of a 2-day history of fever, headache, malaise, and dry cough. The patient lives with her son and his family and her son reports that other members of the family have had similar symptoms during the past week but that he has not had any symptoms. The result of a polymerase chain reaction test confirms that the woman is infected with a virus that has a helical capsid and a segmented genome. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the son being free of symptoms?
A.Serum antibodies against hemagglutinin
B.Downregulation of ICAM-1 expression
C.Protease-resistant antibodies in nasal secretions
D.Homozygous mutation in the CCR5 gene

The patient's symptoms and the confirmation of a virus with a helical capsid and a segmented genome suggest that she is infected with influenza virus. Influenza viruses are known for causing respiratory symptoms such as fever, headache, malaise, and dry cough.

The son's lack of symptoms despite living in the same household as the infected patient is a common phenomenon in influenza. This is because influenza viruses can cause a range of symptoms from asymptomatic to severe illness, and the severity of symptoms can vary greatly between individuals.

The most likely explanation for the son being free of symptoms is that he has developed some level of immunity to the virus. There are several ways in which this could have occurred:

A. Serum antibodies against hemagglutinin - Influenza viruses have a surface protein called hemagglutinin (HA), which is the primary target of the immune system. If the son has developed antibodies against the hemagglutinin of the virus that is circulating in his household, he may be protected from developing symptoms upon exposure.

B. Downregulation of ICAM-1 expression - This is not a common mechanism for immunity to influenza and is not the most likely explanation for the son's lack of symptoms.

C. Protease-resistant antibodies in nasal secretions - This is a mechanism that is more associated with coronaviruses, such as SARS-CoV-2, and is not the most likely explanation for the son's immunity to influenza.

D. Homozygous mutation in the CCR5 gene - This mutation is associated with resistance to HIV infection, not influenza.

Given the options provided, the most likely explanation for the son being free of symptoms is that he has developed antibodies against the hemagglutinin of the influenza virus, which is the primary target of the immune system.

So, the answer is A. Serum antibodies against hemagglutinin. Therefore, the answer is A

A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a generalized rash for 3 days. During this period, he has had severe itching and was not able to sleep well. He has also had fever, headache, and some muscle pain. Five days ago, he had a runny nose which subsided with over-the-counter medications. He returned from a camping trip 1 week ago. He attends a daycare center. The patient is at the 55th percentile for height and at the 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 96/60 mm Hg. Examination of the skin shows several macules, papules, and crusted lesions over his face, trunk, and extremities. There are a few fluid-filled vesicles over his abdomen and back. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A.Measles
B.Urushiol-induced dermatitis
C.Chickenpox
D.Rubella

cot:
<|assistant|>
The clinical presentation of the 4-year-old boy includes a generalized rash, severe itching, fever, headache, muscle pain, and a recent history of a runny nose. The rash is described as macules, papules, and crusted lesions, with some fluid-filled vesicles. The absence of cervical lymphadenopathy is notable.

Let's consider the options:

A. Measles - This is a highly contagious viral infection that typically presents with a prodrome of fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis, followed by a characteristic rash that starts on the face and spreads to the trunk and extremities. The rash is usually maculopapular and can be accompanied by Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa. Measles does not typically cause vesicles.

B. Urticarial-induced dermatitis - This is a type of allergic reaction that presents with hives or welts on the skin. It is not typically associated with fever, headache, or muscle pain, and it does not cause the type of rash described in the question.

C. Chickenpox (Varicella) - This is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus. It typically presents with a prodrome of fever, malaise, and a generalized rash that starts as macules and papules and then progresses to vesicles that eventually crust over. The rash can be itchy and is often described as "dew drops on a rose petal." Chickenpox can also cause lymphadenopathy, which is not mentioned in the case.

D. Rubella - This is a viral infection that is characterized by a rash that starts on the face and spreads to the trunk and extremities. It is often described as a "slapped cheek" rash due to the redness on the cheeks. Rubella is also known for causing a prodrome of fever, malaise, and a runny nose, which is consistent with the patient's history. However, rubella does not typically cause vesicles or the severe itching described in the case.

Given the description of the rash and the absence of lymphadenopathy, the most likely diagnosis is chickenpox. The rash described is consistent with the progression of chickenpox from macules and papules to vesicles, and the severe itching and fever are also typical symptoms.

So, the answer is C. Chickenpox. Therefore, the answer is C

A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of unusual behavior that started 3 hours ago while he was at a party. He has a history of major depressive disorder and seasonal allergies. His mother has a history of anxiety. He drinks 5 beers on the weekends. Current medications include amitriptyline and diphenhydramine. The patient does not respond to questions and repeatedly says, ""The government is following me everywhere."" His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 160/89 mm Hg. He is diaphoretic. He is not oriented to place or time. Neurologic examination shows dilated pupils bilaterally and diffuse hyperreflexia. His feet are cold, and capillary refill time is 3 seconds. After the examination, the patient starts screaming and tries to bite the physician. Urine toxicology screening is positive for ethyl glucuronide. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?"
A.Brief psychotic disorder
B.Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
C.Anticholinergic toxicity
D.Synthetic cathinone intoxication

The patient presents with symptoms of unusual behavior, disorientation, dilated pupils, hyperreflexia, diaphoresis, tachycardia, hypertension, and agitation. These symptoms are suggestive of a central nervous system disturbance. The presence of ethyl glucuronide in the urine toxicology screening indicates recent alcohol consumption.

A. Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by the sudden onset of at least one of the following symptoms: delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, or grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior. While the patient's behavior is unusual, the other symptoms do not fit the criteria for a brief psychotic disorder.

B. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a life-threatening condition that can occur in patients taking antipsychotic medications. It is characterized by fever, muscle rigidity, altered mental status, and autonomic instability. The patient's symptoms do not include muscle rigidity or autonomic instability, which are key features of neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

C. Anticholinergic toxicity is a condition that can occur when a person takes medications that block the action of acetylcholine, such as antihistamines, tricyclic antidepressants, or antipsychotics. Symptoms include dilated pupils, dry skin, confusion, agitation, and hallucinations. The patient's symptoms, particularly the dilated pupils and altered mental status, are consistent with anticholinergic toxicity.

D. Synthetic cathinone intoxication is associated with the use of "bath salts," which are synthetic stimulants. The symptoms of synthetic cathinone intoxication are more likely to include agitation, paranoia, and hallucinations, but the patient's symptoms are more consistent with anticholinergic toxicity.

Given the patient's history of major depressive disorder and the use of amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant, which is known to have anticholinergic effects, the most likely explanation for his symptoms is anticholinergic toxicity.

So, the answer is C. Anticholinergic toxicity. Therefore, the answer is C

A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency room complaining of neck stiffness. He reports that his neck started “locking” three hours ago. He is now unable to move it. His past medical history is notable for schizophrenia and asthma and he currently takes albuterol as well as another medication whose name he does not remember. His temperature is 99.0°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 18/min. On physical examination, the patient appears anxious and diaphoretic. He speaks in full sentences and is oriented to person, place, and time. The patient’s neck is flexed and rotated to the right approximately 40 degrees. The right sternocleidomastoid and trapezius are firm and contracted. Extraocular movements are full and intact. Upon further questioning, he reports that he took more medication four hours ago because he was hearing voices. Which of the following should most likely be administered to this patient?
A.Glycopyrrolate
B.Benztropine
C.Levodopa
D.Dantrolene

The patient's symptoms of neck stiffness, inability to move his neck, and the fact that he took more medication because he was hearing voices suggest that he may be experiencing a dystonic reaction. Dystonic reactions are a type of extrapyramidal side effect that can occur with the use of antipsychotic medications, which are known to cause this side effect.

The most appropriate treatment for a dystonic reaction is an anticholinergic medication. Anticholinergic medications can help to counteract the effects of antipsychotic medications that increase acetylcholine levels in the brain, which can lead to dystonic reactions.

Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic medication that is commonly used to treat dystonic reactions. It works by blocking the action of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, which can help to relieve the symptoms of dystonia.

Benztropine is another anticholinergic medication that can be used to treat dystonic reactions. However, it is not the most commonly used first-line treatment for this condition.

Levodopa is a medication used to treat Parkinson's disease and is not indicated for the treatment of dystonic reactions.

Dantrolene is a medication used to treat malignant hyperthermia and is not indicated for the treatment of dystonic reactions.

Given the information provided and the most likely diagnosis of a dystonic reaction, the most appropriate medication to administer to this patient would be an anticholinergic agent, such as glycopyrrolate.

So, the answer is A. Glycopyrrolate. Therefore, the answer is A

A 13-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. A venous blood sample obtained for routine screening tests is milky. After refrigeration, a creamy supernatant layer appears on top of the sample. Genetic analysis shows a mutation in the apolipoprotein C-II gene (APOC2) on chromosome 19. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following complications?
A.Acute pancreatitis
B.Myocardial infarction
C.Corneal arci
D.Cerebrovascular accident
A

cot:
<|assistant|>
The clinical presentation of a milky blood sample with a creamy supernatant layer after refrigeration is indicative of chylomicronemia, which is a condition where there is an excess of chylomicrons in the blood. Chylomicrons are large lipoproteins that transport dietary fats from the intestine to the liver and other tissues. The presence of a mutation in the apolipoprotein C-II gene (APOC2) suggests a deficiency in this protein, which is a cofactor for lipoprotein lipase, an enzyme that breaks down chylomicrons.

When lipoprotein lipase is deficient or dysfunctional, chylomicrons cannot be broken down properly, leading to an accumulation of chylomicrons in the blood. This can cause a condition known as hyperchylomicronemia, which is characterized by the symptoms described in the question.

The complications associated with hyperchylomicronemia include:

A. Acute pancreatitis - This is a common complication of hyperchylomicronemia because the accumulation of chylomicrons can lead to the precipitation of triglycerides in the pancreas, which can cause inflammation and damage to the pancreas.

B. Myocardial infarction - This is not a direct complication of hyperchylomicronemia. While hypertriglyceridemia can be a risk factor for coronary artery disease, the direct link to myocardial infarction is not as strong as with other lipid disorders.

C. Corneal arcus - This is a condition where there is a white ring around the cornea of the eye. It is associated with hyperlipidemia, but it is not a direct complication of hyperchylomicronemia.

D. Cerebrovascular accident - This is a stroke, which can be caused by atherosclerosis. While hyperlipidemia is a risk factor for atherosclerosis, the direct link to cerebrovascular accidents is not as strong as with other lipid disorders.

Given the options provided, acute pancreatitis is the most likely complication associated with the genetic mutation described in the question.

So, the answer is A. Acute pancreatitis. Therefore, the answer is A

A 9-year-old boy is brought to a physician by his mother for evaluation of generalized weakness, increased urination, and increased thirst. The mother mentions that her boy is always tired, and seems to be getting worse. He prefers watching television rather than going out and playing with other kids. Furthermore, he has had frequent episodes of constipation since birth. Except for frequent cravings for salty foods, the boy eats a regular diet. The patient was delivered healthy and is fully immunized. The medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. He has no siblings. His father is a banker and his mother is a librarian. The pulse is 90/min, the blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg, and the respiratory rate is 15/min. He is in the bottom 10th percentile for height and weight according to his age. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. He recently had a urinalysis that showed elevated urinary calcium excretion.
Additional lab testing results are as follows:
Serum electrolytes
Sodium 135 mEq/L
Potassium 3.2 mEq/L
Chloride 95 mEq/L
Plasma renin activity 10 ng/mL/hr (normal, 0.5–3.3 ng/mL/hr)
Plasma aldosterone concentration 20 ng/dL (normal, 2–9 ng/dL)
What is the most likely diagnosis?
A.Renal artery stenosis
B.Bartter's syndrome
C.Pheochromocytoma
D.Gitelman's syndrome
B

cot:
<|assistant|>
The patient presents with symptoms of generalized weakness, increased urination, increased thirst, fatigue, and a preference for sedentary activities. These symptoms, along with the history of frequent constipation and a recent urinalysis showing elevated urinary calcium excretion, suggest a possible endocrine disorder.

The laboratory findings of low plasma renin activity (PRA) and low plasma aldosterone concentration (PAC) are particularly noteworthy. Normally, when the body is low on sodium, the kidneys respond by secreting renin, which leads to the production of angiotensin II. Angiotensin II then stimulates the adrenal glands to release aldosterone, which increases sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion. In this patient, the PRA is low, indicating that the kidneys are not responding appropriately to low sodium levels, and the PAC is also low, suggesting that the adrenal glands are not responding to the stimulus to produce aldosterone.

Given these findings, we can consider the following conditions:

A. Renal artery stenosis typically leads to high renin levels, not low, as the kidneys would be trying to compensate for decreased blood flow by secreting more renin.

B. Bartter's syndrome is characterized by hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and hyperreninemia, which is the opposite of what is seen in this patient.

C. Pheochromocytoma is a tumor of the adrenal medulla that secretes catecholamines, which can lead to hypertension and other symptoms. However, the patient's blood pressure is normal, and the symptoms are not typical of pheochromocytoma.

D. Gitelman's syndrome is a genetic disorder that leads to hypocalciuria, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and hyperreninemia. However, the patient's urinary calcium excretion is elevated, which is not consistent with Gitelman's syndrome.

The most likely diagnosis given the patient's symptoms and laboratory findings is a condition that leads to low renin and low aldosterone levels. One such condition is Gordon's syndrome, also known as familial hyperkalemic hypertension or pseudohypoaldosteronism type II. This condition is characterized by hypertension, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis, which can be seen in this patient's presentation.

So, the answer is D. Gitelman's syndrome. Therefore, the answer is D

A 5-year-old boy of African descent is presented to the emergency department by his parents. The child is clutching his abdomen and crying about pain in his belly. His mother reports intermittent episodes of jaundice with joint and bone pain since he was 5 months old. At presentation, the patient’s vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals slight jaundice and pale conjunctiva. The spleen is tender and easily palpable. After a complete blood count with differential and an abdominal ultrasound, the patient is found to have sickle-cell disease with splenic infarct. A partial splenectomy is performed. After the operation, the physician provides vaccines against Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae, and Streptococcus pneumoniae. The picture shows a slide obtained from the resected portion of the patient’s spleen. Dysfunction of the zone marked with which number predisposes the patient to the aforementioned infections?
A.2 only
B.1 only
C.1 and 2
D.1, 2, and 3
C

cot:
<|assistant|>
The patient has sickle-cell disease, which is a genetic disorder characterized by the presence of abnormal hemoglobin (HbS) in red blood cells. This abnormal hemoglobin can cause the cells to become sickle-shaped, which can lead to various complications, including splenic infarcts.

The spleen is an important part of the immune system, particularly in the early stages of life. It filters the blood and removes old or damaged red blood cells, as well as pathogens. The spleen also produces antibodies and stores white blood cells.

In sickle-cell disease, the spleen can become enlarged due to chronic inflammation and can be prone to infarction. After a partial splenectomy, the patient is at increased risk for infections because the spleen is a key part of the immune system, especially in the early stages of life.

The spleen is divided into two zones: the red pulp and the white pulp. The red pulp is responsible for filtering the blood and removing old or damaged red blood cells. The white pulp is where the immune response is initiated and where lymphocytes are produced.

The white pulp is further divided into three zones: the marginal zone, the periarteriolar lymphoid sheath (PALS), and the germinal center. The marginal zone is the outermost layer of the white pulp and is the first line of defense against blood-borne pathogens. It contains B cells that are responsible for producing antibodies against encapsulated bacteria such as Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae, and Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Given that the patient is at increased risk for infections due to the partial splenectomy, the dysfunction of the marginal zone (zone 2) would predispose the patient to the infections listed.

So, the answer is A.2 only. Therefore, the answer is A

The presence of high titers of anti-Ro and anti-La autoantibodies further supports this diagnosis.

Sjögren's syndrome is associated with an increased risk of certain malignancies, including non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). A 59-year-old man presents to his primary care provider with fatigue, a progressively worsening cough with flecks of blood, shortness of breath, and dark urine. He reports feeling ill for the past 3 weeks. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He takes chlorthalidone and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. He has smoked 20–30 cigarettes daily for the past 26 years. Anti-glomerular basement membrane serologies are positive. Which of the following is a specific feature for this patient’s condition?
A.Granulomatous inflammation and necrotizing vasculitis
B.Positive cryoglobulins
C.Linear IgG staining on immunofluorescence
D.Longitudinal splitting and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane

The patient's symptoms of fatigue, a progressively worsening cough with flecks of blood, shortness of breath, and dark urine, along with a history of smoking and a positive anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) serology, are highly suggestive of Goodpasture's syndrome. Goodpasture's syndrome is an autoimmune disease characterized by the production of antibodies against the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), which leads to glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage.

The specific feature of Goodpasture's syndrome is the presence of anti-GBM antibodies, which are detected by a positive anti-GBM serology. These antibodies are directed against the noncollagenous domain of the alpha-3 chain of type IV collagen, which is a component of the GBM.

The other options listed do not specifically relate to Goodpasture's syndrome:

A. Granulomatous inflammation and necrotizing vasculitis are more characteristic of conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis) or microscopic polyangiitis, which are not indicated by the patient's presentation or serology results.

B. Positive cryoglobulins are associated with cryoglobulinemia, which is not indicated by the patient's presentation or serology results.

C. Linear IgG staining on immunofluorescence is a feature of anti-GBM disease, but it is not a specific feature of Goodpasture's syndrome. It is a general finding in diseases where there is deposition of IgG along the GBM.

D. Longitudinal splitting and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane are also features of anti-GBM disease, but they are not specific to Goodpasture's syndrome. They are also seen in other conditions such as Alport syndrome and hereditary nephritis.

Given the patient's symptoms and the positive anti-GBM serology, the specific feature of Goodpasture's syndrome is the presence of anti-GBM antibodies.

So, the answer is C. Linear IgG staining on immunofluorescence. Therefore, the answer is C

A 32-year-old man with HIV infection is brought to the emergency department by his roommate because of a 2-week history of progressively worsening headache and vomiting. Current medications include trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dolutegravir, and tenofovir-emtricitabine. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination shows nuchal rigidity. Kernig and Brudzinski signs are present. A lumbar puncture is performed and shows an opening pressure of 32 cm H2O (N: < 20). The pathogen isolated from the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) can be cultured on Sabouraud agar. Further evaluation of this patient's CSF is most likely to show which of the following additional findings?

C.Presence of tachyzoites

The patient's symptoms and signs, including a high fever, headache, vomiting, nuchal rigidity, Kernig and Brudzinski signs, and a high opening pressure on lumbar puncture, are suggestive of meningitis. The fact that the pathogen isolated from the CSF can be cultured on Sabouraud agar indicates that it is a fungus, which is consistent with Cryptococcus neoformans, a common cause of fungal meningitis in immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV infection.

Cryptococcus neoformans is known to cause cryptococcal meningitis, which is characterized by the presence of encapsulated yeast cells in the CSF. The latex agglutination test is a rapid diagnostic test that can detect the presence of cryptococcal antigen in the CSF, which is a specific and sensitive test for cryptococcal meningitis.

PCR for HSV-2 DNA would be used to diagnose herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) infection, which is not indicated by the clinical presentation or the culture results.

The presence of tachyzoites would be indicative of toxoplasmosis, which is another common opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients, but the culture on Sabouraud agar would not be used for toxoplasmosis.

Increased adenosine deaminase concentration is associated with tuberculous meningitis, which is not indicated by the culture results.

Given the information provided and the typical presentation of cryptococcal meningitis, the most likely additional finding in the CSF would be a positive latex agglutination test for cryptococcal antigen.

So, the answer is A. Positive latex agglutination test. Therefore, the answer is A

The patient's symptoms and presentation are suggestive of herpes zoster, also known as shingles. Her symptoms of a burning pain in her upper right back and chest, along with the rash that extends from her back to below her right breast, are classic for this condition. Her age and the fact that she volunteers at an animal shelter are risk factors for herpes zoster, as it is more common in older adults and can be transmitted from animals to humans.

The underlying mechanism of herpes zoster is the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which causes chickenpox in children and shingles in adults. The virus remains dormant in the dorsal root ganglia after a primary infection with chickenpox and can reactivate later in life, leading to the symptoms of shingles.

It is determined that patients have a 4-year asymptomatic period prior to developing clinical symptoms from this adrenal cancer. A new screening test is developed, and the cancer can now be detected 2 years prior to developing clinical symptoms. A new observational case-control study of screened and unscreened patients measures the median 5-year survival of patients who decline medical and surgical treatment. The screened population has statistically better outcomes. Which step should be undertaken to prevent bias in these conclusions?
A.Using survival rates in the analysis
B.Using mortality rates in the analysis
C.Increasing the number of screened individuals
D.Decreasing the number of screened individuals

The question describes a scenario where a new screening test has been developed for a fatal adrenal cancer, and the cancer can now be detected 2 years prior to developing clinical symptoms. A new observational case-control study is conducted to measure the median 5-year survival of patients who decline medical and surgical treatment. The screened population has statistically better outcomes.

To prevent bias in these conclusions, we need to ensure that the comparison between the screened and unscreened populations is fair. One way to do this is to ensure that the groups are comparable in terms of their characteristics, including the severity of their disease and their willingness to undergo treatment.

The use of survival rates (A) or mortality rates (B) in the analysis is not the primary concern here. The issue is that the screened population may have a different composition from the unscreened population, which could lead to biased results.

Increasing the number of screened individuals (C) would not necessarily address the issue of bias. It could potentially increase the number of false positives, which could lead to unnecessary treatment and its associated risks.

Decreasing the number of screened individuals (D) would also not address the issue of bias. It could lead to a smaller sample size, which might not be sufficient to detect differences in outcomes.

The best way to prevent bias in this scenario is to ensure that the screened and unscreened populations are comparable in terms of their characteristics. This could be done by matching the groups on relevant variables, such as age, gender, and disease severity, to ensure that the comparison is fair.

So, the answer is A. Using survival rates in the analysis. While this is not the primary concern, it is a step that could be taken to ensure that the analysis is done correctly and that the results are not biased by the use of survival rates. Therefore, the answer is A

The absence of significant findings on the ECG and the lack of a history of coronary artery disease make the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction less likely.

Atrial fibrillation (A) is a common arrhythmia that can lead to heart failure, but it typically presents with palpitations, shortness of breath, and other symptoms that are not mentioned in the case. Additionally, atrial fibrillation would not typically cause an S3 heart sound or rales.

Constrictive pericarditis (B) is a condition where the pericardium becomes thickened and noncompliant, leading to impaired ventricular filling. It can present with symptoms similar to heart failure, but it is less likely to cause an S3 heart sound or rales.

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (C), also known as stress cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome, is a condition where the heart muscle is temporarily weakened after a sudden emotional or physical stress. It can present with chest pain and heart failure symptoms, but it is less likely to cause an S3 heart sound or rales.

Restrictive cardiomyopathy (D) is a condition where the heart muscle becomes stiff and less compliant, leading to impaired ventricular filling. It can present with symptoms similar to heart failure, but it is less likely to cause an S3 heart sound or rales.

Given the patient's recent emotional stress, the presence of an S3 heart sound, and the echocardiographic findings of an enlarged left ventricle and left atrium, the most likely diagnosis is Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. This condition is known to be triggered by emotional stress and can present with symptoms similar to those of heart failure, including chest pain and signs of heart failure on examination.

So, the answer is C. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Therefore, the answer is C

A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department. He was found unconscious on the street. The staff recognizes him as a local homeless man with a long history of alcoholism. At the hospital, his pulse is 95/min, the blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, the respirations are 20/min, and the oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, the unconscious man is covered in bloody vomit with small clots and food particles. He smells of alcohol. A digital exam reveals black tarry stool in the rectal vault. The patient is given oxygen, IV fluids, and an NG-tube is placed and set to intermittent suction. Labs are sent and the patient is prepared for a procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in his management?
A.Undergo colonoscopy
B.Undergo upper GI endoscopy
C.Proton pump inhibitors with anti-H.pylori regimen
D.Surgery for peptic ulcer disease
B

cot:
<|assistant|>
The patient presents with a history of alcoholism, unconsciousness, and signs of gastrointestinal bleeding, as evidenced by the bloody vomit, black tarry stool, and the presence of food particles and clots. These findings suggest a gastrointestinal bleed, which could be from either the upper or lower gastrointestinal tract.

Given the patient's history of alcoholism, one of the most common causes of upper gastrointestinal bleeding is peptic ulcer disease, which can be caused by Helicobacter pylori infection or the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). The presence of black tarry stool is a classic sign of upper gastrointestinal bleeding, as it is indicative of digested blood (melena).

The most appropriate next step in the management of this patient would be to identify the source of the bleeding and treat it accordingly. An upper GI endoscopy is the best initial diagnostic and therapeutic procedure for upper gastrointestinal bleeding. It allows for direct visualization of the upper gastrointestinal tract, including the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum, and can be used to diagnose and treat the source of bleeding, such as a peptic ulcer, varices, or other lesions.

Colonoscopy (option A) is not the most appropriate next step because the patient's symptoms and signs point towards an upper gastrointestinal bleed, not a lower gastrointestinal bleed.

Proton pump inhibitors with an anti-H. pylori regimen (option C) could be considered if the patient were found to have a peptic ulcer or H. pylori infection, but this would be a treatment step after the source of bleeding has been identified and treated.

Surgery for peptic ulcer disease (option D) is a treatment option if the bleeding is not controlled with endoscopic therapy or if there are complications such as perforation or obstruction. However, this is not the most appropriate next step before attempting endoscopic therapy.

So, the answer is B. Undergo upper GI endoscopy. Therefore, the answer is B

An 8-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of hematuria. Two weeks ago, she had a sore throat that resolved without treatment. Physical examination shows 1+ pitting edema of the lower legs and ankles. Urinalysis shows numerous RBCs and 3+ proteinuria. Her antistreptolysin O titer is elevated. Formation of which of the following is most likely involved in the underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms?
A.Antigen-specific IgE binding to mast cells
B.Tissue-specific antibodies
C.Antigen-antibody complexes
D.Presensitized CD8+ cytotoxic T-cells
C

cot:
<|assistant|>
The clinical presentation of the 8-year-old girl with hematuria, pitting edema, and proteinuria, along with an elevated antistreptolysin O titer, suggests that she has post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). PSGN is a type of glomerulonephritis that occurs after a streptococcal infection, typically a throat infection, as in this case.

The formation of antigen-antibody complexes is a key step in the pathogenesis of PSGN. After a streptococcal infection, the immune system produces antibodies against the streptococcal antigens. These antibodies can then bind to the antigens on the surface of the glomerular basement membrane, leading to the formation of immune complexes. These immune complexes can deposit in the glomeruli, triggering an inflammatory response that damages the glomerular capillaries and leads to the symptoms of PSGN, such as hematuria, proteinuria, and edema.

The other options listed do not fit the mechanism of PSGN:

A. Antigen-specific IgE binding to mast cells is more characteristic of allergic reactions, not glomerulonephritis.
B. Tissue-specific antibodies are not typically involved in the pathogenesis of PSGN.
D. Presensitized CD8+ cytotoxic T-cells are not the primary mechanism in the pathogenesis of PSGN.

So, the answer is C. Antigen-antibody complexes. Therefore, the answer is C

A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. He was found down in the middle of the street. His past medical history is unknown. His temperature is 99.0°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 104/64 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, respirations are 5/min, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. The patient is being resuscitated in the trauma bay. Which of the following was most likely to be found on exam?
A.Ataxia
B.Conjunctival injection
C.Miosis
D.Nystagmus
C

<|assistant|>
The patient presents with altered mental status and is found down in the street, which suggests a possible overdose or intoxication. The vital signs are significant for a low respiratory rate (5/min) and low oxygen saturation (91% on room air), which could indicate respiratory depression or hypoxemia.

Let's consider the options:

A. Ataxia is a lack of muscle coordination, which could be seen in conditions such as alcohol intoxication or cerebellar disorders.

B. Conjunctival injection is a sign of inflammation or irritation, which could be seen in various conditions, including allergies, infections, or drug use.

C. Miosis is the constriction of the pupils, which is a classic sign of opioid overdose. Opioids can cause respiratory depression and hypoxemia, which are consistent with the patient's symptoms.

D. Nystagmus is an involuntary, rapid, rhythmic movement of the eyes, which can be seen in various conditions, including drug intoxication, but it is not as specific as miosis for opioid overdose.

Given the clinical presentation and the need for resuscitation, the most likely finding on exam would be miosis, which is a sign of opioid overdose.

So, the answer is C. Miosis. Therefore, the answer is C

A 38-year-old G4P3 presents to her obstetrician’s office for her 20-week anatomy ultrasound. She reports that she feels well and has not experienced any contractions or vaginal bleeding. She also reports good fetal movement. The patient declined prenatal screening earlier in the pregnancy for religious reasons but would now like an anatomy ultrasound to ensure the fetus is growing appropriately. The patient’s previous pregnancies were uncomplicated, and she delivered three healthy babies at full term. On the ultrasound, the technician observes a male fetus with likely intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). She also notes microcephaly, convex-rounded feet, and clenched fists with overlapping fingers. The technician further notes a medium-sized ventricular septal defect (VSD). The amniotic fluid index (AFI) is 26 cm.

Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be observed in this fetus?
A.Cleft palate
B.Epicanthal folds
C.Micropthlamia
D.Prominent occiput

The fetus described in the scenario has several features that are suggestive of a chromosomal abnormality. The presence of intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), microcephaly, and congenital heart defects, such as a ventricular septal defect (VSD), are common findings in conditions like trisomy 21 (Down syndrome). Additionally, the presence of convex-rounded feet, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, and a medium-sized VSD are characteristic of trisomy 21.

Trisomy 21 is associated with a variety of facial features, including epicanthal folds, which are folds of skin that cover the inner corner of the eye. These folds are not typically associated with other chromosomal abnormalities or syndromes.

A cleft palate is a congenital defect that involves the palate, the roof of the mouth. It is not commonly associated with trisomy 21.

Micropthalmia is a condition where one or both eyes are abnormally small. It is not typically associated with trisomy 21.

A prominent occiput is a feature of some genetic conditions, but it is not a typical finding in trisomy 21.

Given the clinical picture and the common associations with trisomy 21, the most likely additional finding in this fetus would be epicanthal folds.

So, the answer is B. Epicanthal folds. Therefore, the answer is B

An 83-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with fever, weakness, and decreased responsiveness. He is diagnosed with urosepsis based on urinalysis and culture and started on ceftriaxone and intravenous fluids. By hospital day 3, he is clinically improving. During the evening, the patient becomes irritable. He is talking to someone despite nobody being present in the room. He is easily agitated and attempts to strike a nurse with a remote control to his TV. Subsequently, the patient keeps getting out of bed and trying to walk away despite being a fall risk. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A.Diphenhydramine
B.Lorazepam
C.Olanzapine
D.Physical restraints
C

cot:
<|assistant|>
The patient's symptoms of irritability, talking to someone who is not present, agitation, and attempting to strike a nurse with a remote control, followed by getting out of bed and trying to walk away, are suggestive of delirium. Delirium is a common complication in hospitalized patients, especially those with serious illnesses like urosepsis. It is characterized by an acute change in mental status and can be associated with confusion, disorientation, hallucinations, and agitation.

The most appropriate next step in management for delirium in a hospitalized patient is to use a non-pharmacological approach first. This includes ensuring that the patient's environment is safe and comfortable, maintaining a regular sleep-wake cycle, and providing orientation to the time, place, and person. Physical restraints should be used as a last resort and only when necessary to ensure the safety of the patient and others.

Pharmacological interventions are used when non-pharmacological measures are not sufficient to manage the symptoms of delirium. Among the options provided, lorazepam is a benzodiazepine that can be used to manage agitation and delirium. However, it is not the first-line treatment and should be used with caution due to the risk of oversedation and respiratory depression, especially in an elderly patient.

Diphenhydramine is an antihistamine that can be used to treat allergic reactions but is not indicated for the management of delirium.

Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic that can be used to manage delirium, but it is not the first-line treatment and should be used with caution in the elderly due to the risk of side effects such as falls and anticholinergic effects.

Given the patient's symptoms and the need to manage his delirium, the most appropriate next step in management would be to use non-pharmacological measures first, followed by pharmacological intervention if necessary. Physical restraints should be used as a last resort.

So, the answer is D. Physical restraints. Therefore, the answer is D

A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, weight loss, and muscle aches during the past 2 months. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Her only medication is a multivitamin. A metyrapone stimulation test is performed and the results rule out a diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency. Which of the following changes in laboratory findings are most likely to have been observed in this patient following the administration of the drug?
A.Increase in serum ACTH
B.Decrease in urinary 17-hydroxycorticosteroids
C.Decrease in serum 11-deoxycortisol
D.Increase in serum cortisol
A

cot:
<|assistant|>
The metyrapone stimulation test is used to diagnose adrenal insufficiency, particularly primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease). The test involves administering metyrapone, which inhibits the enzyme 11-beta-hydroxylase, which is responsible for converting 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol. If the patient has normal adrenal function, the body will compensate by increasing the production of ACTH, which stimulates the adrenal glands to produce more cortisol. Since the patient's metyrapone stimulation test ruled out adrenal insufficiency, we can infer that her adrenal glands are functioning normally.

Given this information, we can expect the following changes in laboratory findings:

A. Increase in serum ACTH - This is correct because the body would increase ACTH production in response to the inhibition of cortisol synthesis by metyrapone.

B. Decrease in urinary 17-hydroxycorticosteroids - This is incorrect because the test would not affect the excretion of 17-hydroxycorticosteroids, which are a group of steroids that include cortisol and other adrenal hormones.

C. Decrease in serum 11-deoxycortisol - This is incorrect because metyrapone inhibits the conversion of 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol, which would lead to an increase in 11-deoxycortisol, not a decrease.

D. Increase in serum cortisol - This is incorrect because metyrapone inhibits the conversion of 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol, which would lead to a decrease in serum cortisol, not an increase.

So, the answer is A. Increase in serum ACTH. Therefore, the answer is A

An investigator conducts a study to determine whether earlier detection of glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) in patients increases survival time. One subset of study participants consists of asymptomatic individuals who were diagnosed with GBM after undergoing a screening MRI of the brain. The other subset of study participants was diagnosed with GBM only after they developed symptoms. Results from the study show that the asymptomatic patients who were diagnosed with screening MRI had an average survival time that was 6 weeks longer than that of the patients who were diagnosed after symptom onset. Which of the following statistical biases is most likely to have occurred as a result of the endpoint selected for this study?
A.Observer-expectancy bias
B.Length-time bias
C.Surveillance bias
D.Lead-time bias
D

cot:
<|assistant|>
The study in question is comparing the survival time of patients with glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) who were diagnosed after undergoing a screening MRI (asymptomatic) to those who were diagnosed after developing symptoms. The key difference between these two groups is the timing of diagnosis, which is influenced by the screening process.

The statistical bias that is most likely to have occurred in this study is lead-time bias. Lead-time bias occurs when the time between diagnosis and the actual onset of disease is artificially increased due to earlier detection. In this case, the asymptomatic patients who were diagnosed with GBM after a screening MRI had a longer survival time compared to those who were diagnosed after symptom onset. However, this longer survival time may not be due to a true increase in the duration of the disease but rather due to the earlier detection of the disease through screening, which simply shifts the time of diagnosis earlier in the disease course.

Observer-expectancy bias is when the observer's expectations influence the outcome of the study. This is not the case here as the study is not subjective and the outcome is based on objective data.

Length-time bias is when a screening test is more likely to detect slower-growing tumors than faster-growing tumors. This is not the case here as the study is not comparing the effectiveness of a screening test but rather the impact of earlier diagnosis on survival.

Surveillance bias is when the study population is selected based on their participation in a screening program. This is not the case here as the study population is not selected based on their participation in a screening program but rather on the timing of their diagnosis.

So, the answer is D. Lead-time bias. Therefore, the answer is D

A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the restrained driver. On questioning by the paramedics, he reported severe chest pain and mild dyspnea. On arrival, he is confused and unable to provide a history. His pulse is 93/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 91/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. He is able to move his extremities in response to commands. He opens his eyes spontaneously. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination shows multiple bruises over the trunk and extremities. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) wound at the left fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line. There is jugular venous distention. Decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance on percussion are noted on the left. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A.CT scan of the chest
B.Bronchoscopy
C.Emergency thoracotomy
D.Needle decompression
D

cot:
<|assistant|>
The patient presents with severe chest pain, mild dyspnea, confusion, and hypotension following a high-speed motor vehicle collision. The presence of a wound at the left fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line, along with decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance on percussion, suggests a possible pneumothorax. A pneumothorax is a condition where air accumulates in the space between the lung and the chest wall, which can lead to decreased lung function and potentially life-threatening complications.

The most immediate concern in this scenario is the patient's hypotension and hypoxemia (oxygen saturation of 88% on room air). These symptoms could be due to a tension pneumothorax, which is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate intervention to prevent further compromise of the patient's respiratory and circulatory systems.

The most appropriate next step in management for a suspected tension pneumothorax is needle decompression. This procedure involves inserting a large-bore needle into the pleural space to relieve the pressure and allow the lung to re-expand. This can be performed quickly and without the need for imaging or other invasive procedures that might delay treatment.

A CT scan of the chest (option A) would be useful for further evaluation of the chest trauma, but it is not the immediate next step in management for a suspected tension pneumothorax. Bronchoscopy (option B) is not indicated in this scenario as there is no suspicion of airway injury or foreign body aspiration. An emergency thoracotomy (option C) is a surgical procedure that is reserved for cases where there is a need to open the chest cavity to repair life-threatening injuries, which is not indicated at this point without further evidence of such injuries.

So, the answer is D. Needle decompression. Therefore, the answer is D

A novel type of PET radiotracer is being developed to evaluate patients with Parkinson’s disease. A clinical research study has enrolled 1,200 patients, half of whom have the disease. The scan is found to be positive in 590 of the 600 patients with known PD, and positive in 20 of the 600 patients without PD. What is the test’s overall specificity?
A.580 / (20 + 590)
B.580 / (10 + 580)
C.590 / (590 + 10)
D.580 / (580 + 20)
D

cot:
<|assistant|>
To calculate the specificity of a test, we need to know the number of true negatives (TN) and the number of false positives (FP). The specificity is calculated as TN / (TN + FP).

In this case, we have the following information:

- The test is positive in 590 of the 600 patients with known PD, which means that 10 patients with PD have a negative test result. This is the number of false negatives (FN).
- The test is positive in 20 of the 600 patients without PD, which means that 580 patients without PD have a negative test result. This is the number of true negatives (TN).

Now, we can calculate the specificity as follows:

Specificity = TN / (TN + FP)
Specificity = 580 / (580 + 20)

So, the answer is B.580 / (10 + 580). Therefore, the answer is B

A 55-year-old man presents to a rheumatologist with bilateral wrist and knee pain that has been present for the last 10 years. The patient was a professional athlete who retired at age 50. He also notes morning stiffness in his joints that lasts approx. 50 minutes. He denies joint swelling, color changes in his digits, dryness of mucous membranes, and constitutional symptoms such as fever and chills. On physical exam, the physician notes several non-tender nodules on the left 1st, 3rd, and 4th distal interphalangeal joints. There is also tenderness with palpation at the base of both thumbs. The patient’s knees are enlarged, bilaterally, and he has pain and crepitus on passive range of motion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A.Ankylosing spondylitis
B.Gout
C.Osteoarthritis
D.Fibromyalgia
C

cot:
<|assistant|>
The patient's history of being a professional athlete and the presence of morning stiffness that lasts for 50 minutes are key points in the differential diagnosis. Morning stiffness that lasts for more than 30 minutes is a common symptom of inflammatory arthritis, such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA), whereas morning stiffness that lasts less than 30 minutes is more typical of osteoarthritis (OA).

The presence of non-tender nodules on the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints and tenderness at the base of the thumbs (Bouchard's nodes) are characteristic of osteoarthritis. These nodules are not typically seen in RA, which is more likely to affect the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints. Additionally, the patient's knees are enlarged and painful, which is consistent with osteoarthritis.

Ankylosing spondylitis typically presents with sacroiliitis and spinal involvement, which is not mentioned in the case. Gout is characterized by acute, episodic attacks of severe pain, redness, and swelling in joints, often the big toe, and is not consistent with the chronic, non-tender nodules described in this case. Fibromyalgia is a chronic pain syndrome characterized by widespread pain and tenderness, which is not described in this case.

Given the patient's history, symptoms, and physical exam findings, the most likely diagnosis is osteoarthritis.

So, the answer is C. Osteoarthritis. Therefore, the answer is C

A 40-year-old businessman who was previously well is brought into the emergency department by his assistant with a complaint of left-sided weakness after a chiropractic neck manipulation. He has never felt like this before. Past medical history is insignificant. His blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg, pulse 86/min, respiratory rate 13/min, temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F). A T2-weighted MRI shows a left C5 hemicord lesion. The patient is treated with cervical immobilization, a course of steroids, and physical therapy. What other finding will most likely be seen in this patient?
A.Spastic paralysis at the level of lesion
B.Right-sided Horner's syndrome
C.Contralateral corticospinal tract involvement
D.Right-sided analgesia
D

cot:
<|assistant|>
The patient has a history of a chiropractic neck manipulation that led to a left-sided weakness, which is indicative of a neurological injury. The MRI shows a left C5 hemicord lesion, which suggests that the injury is to the left side of the spinal cord at the C5 level.

The spinal cord is divided into two halves, the right and left hemicords, which are connected by the anterior and posterior white commissures. The hemicords contain the ascending and descending tracts that carry sensory and motor information, respectively.

Given that the lesion is on the left side of the spinal cord, the right side of the body will be affected. This is because the left side of the spinal cord controls the right side of the body, and vice versa.

The right side of the body will be affected by the lesion because the left side of the spinal cord controls the right side of the body. This means that the right side of the body will be affected by the lesion.

A. Spastic paralysis at the level of lesion - This would be seen if the lesion affected the corticospinal tract, which is responsible for motor control. Since the lesion is on the left side of the spinal cord, the right side of the body would be affected, and spastic paralysis would be seen on the right side.

B. Right-sided Horner's syndrome - This is a condition that affects the sympathetic nervous system and would not be directly related to a lesion in the spinal cord.

C. Contralateral corticospinal tract involvement - This would be seen if the lesion affected the corticospinal tract, which is responsible for motor control. Since the lesion is on the left side of the spinal cord, the right side of the body would be affected, and contralateral corticospinal tract involvement would be seen on the right side.

D. Right-sided analgesia - This would be seen if the lesion affected the spinothalamic tract, which is responsible for carrying pain and temperature sensations. Since the lesion is on the left side of the spinal cord, the right side of the body would be affected, and right-sided analgesia would be seen.

Given the options, the most likely finding in this patient would be right-sided analgesia, as the lesion is on the left side of the spinal cord and the right side of the body would be affected.

So, the answer is D. Right-sided analgesia. Therefore, the answer is D

A previously healthy 19-year-old man comes to the physician with right-sided, dull, throbbing scrotal pain for 12 hours. He has also had a burning sensation on urination and increased urinary frequency for the past 3 days. He has not had urethral discharge. He is sexually active with one female partner and does not use condoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a tender right testicle; lifting it provides relief. The penis appears normal, with no discharge at the meatus. Laboratory studies show a normal complete blood count; urinalysis shows 3 WBC/hpf. A Gram stain of a urethral swab shows polymorphonuclear leukocytes but no organisms. Testicular ultrasound shows increased blood flow to the right testicle compared to the left. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
A.Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection
B.Testicular tumor
C.Chlamydia trachomatis infection
D.Varicocele
C

<|assistant|>
The patient presents with right-sided, dull, throbbing scrotal pain, a burning sensation on urination, and increased urinary frequency. These symptoms are suggestive of epididymitis, which is inflammation of the epididymis, a structure that stores and carries sperm. The pain is often described as dull and throbbing, and it can be relieved by elevating the testicle, as the patient has experienced.

The absence of urethral discharge and the presence of polymorphonuclear leukocytes on a urethral swab without any organisms seen on Gram stain make a sexually transmitted infection less likely. Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically causes urethritis with purulent discharge, and Chlamydia trachomatis can cause urethritis but is less likely to cause the acute scrotal pain described.

A testicular tumor would not typically present with the acute onset of pain and would not be associated with increased blood flow to the testicle on ultrasound. Varicocele is a common cause of scrotal pain and swelling, but it is characterized by a "bag of worms" sensation and is not typically associated with the acute onset of pain or increased blood flow to the testicle.

Given the acute onset of pain, the relief provided by elevating the testicle, and the increased blood flow to the right testicle on ultrasound, the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is epididymitis. This condition is often caused by a bacterial infection, but the absence of organisms on the Gram stain makes it less likely to be a sexually transmitted infection.

So, the answer is B. Testicular tumor. Therefore, the answer is B

Urinalysis shows cloudy, red urine. This patient's clinical presentation is best explained by an infection with a virus with which of the following features?
A.Non-enveloped with linear, single-stranded DNA
B.Non-enveloped with linear, single-stranded RNA

The clinical presentation of dysuria and increased urinary frequency, along with cloudy, red urine, is suggestive of a urinary tract infection (UTI). The most common cause of UTIs in young children is Escherichia coli, which is a bacterium. However, the question is asking about a virus.

Viruses are classified based on their structure and the type of nucleic acid they contain. The options provided are:

A. Non-enveloped with linear, single-stranded DNA - This describes adenoviruses, which can cause respiratory infections, conjunctivitis, and gastroenteritis, but not typically UTIs.
B. Non-enveloped with linear, single-stranded RNA - This describes picornaviruses, which include the poliovirus, coxsackievirus, and echovirus. These viruses can cause a variety of illnesses, including respiratory infections, gastroenteritis, and meningitis, but not typically UTIs.
C. Enveloped with linear, single-stranded RNA - This describes the paramyxoviruses, which include the parainfluenza viruses, mumps virus, and respiratory syncytial virus. These viruses can cause respiratory infections, but not typically UTIs.
D. Non-enveloped with linear, double-stranded DNA - This describes the adenoviruses, which can cause respiratory infections, conjunctivitis, and gastroenteritis, but not typically UTIs.

Given the clinical presentation of a UTI, the most likely virus to cause this infection would be a bacterium, not a virus. However, if we were to consider a virus, the most likely candidate would be a non-enveloped virus with linear, single-stranded DNA, which is characteristic of the adenoviruses. Adenoviruses can cause respiratory infections, but they can also cause cystitis and urethritis, which could present with dysuria and increased urinary frequency.

So, the answer is A. Non-enveloped with linear, single-stranded DNA. Therefore, the answer is A

A 13-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician due to a left breast lump under his nipple. He noticed it last month and felt that it has increased slightly in size. It is tender to touch but has no overlying skin changes. There is no breast discharge. The patient has cryptorchidism as an infant and underwent a successful orchiopexy. In addition, he was recently diagnosed with ADHD and is currently on methylphenidate with improvement in his symptoms. He has a family history of type I diabetes in his father and breast fibroadenoma in his mother. On exam, the patient is at the 82nd percentile for height, 79th percentile for weight, and 80th percentile for BMI. He has tanner IV pubic hair. Testicular volume is 7 mL on each side, and both testes are smooth and freely mobile. Breast exam shows a normal right breast and a 3-centimeter round, firm, and slightly tender discrete mass under the left nipple. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
A.Klinefelter syndrome
B.Glandular tissue enlargement
C.Lipomastia (pseudogynecomastia)
D.Testicular cancer
